ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LORONG 8, TOA PAYOH
(Request for tennis and squash facilities)


    1. Mr Ivan Baptist asked the Prime Minister whether the People's Association will request from the Housing and Development Board the landscaped area at the gable-end of Block 222, Lorong 8, Toa Payoh, to be utilised for building a community centre mainly for tennis and squash activities as at present no mich facilities are handy for the people in the ama, especially the Lorong 8 residents.

     The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not the policy of People's Association to build community centres mainly for tennis and squash activities. Community centres are meant to cater for the social, educational and recreational needs of the people.

    The site referred to by the hon. Member is in Neighbourhood 4, Toa Payoh, which has about 1,400 units of 4-room and 5-room flats.

    The People's Association has at present no plan to build a now community centre at Lorong 8 as Potong Pasir Constituency is already served by the Sennett and Potong Pasir Community Centres. The present size of the population in this neighbourhood is too small to warrant a new centre. The needs of the residents in Lorong 8 am, however, well catered for by the facilities including tennis and squash courts at the Sennett Community Centre. They can also avail themselves of the facilities at three new community centres, namely, Boon Teck, Whampoa and Kim Keat just 1 to 2 km away in the neighbouring constituencies.

     Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Posir): Sir, does the Senior Minister of State not realise that the three community centres near the vicinity mentioned do not provide for tennis and

Column: 306

squash facilities, and that the Sennett Community Centre is more than 4 km away from Lorong 8, Toa Payoh?

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Sir, the new Kim Keat Community Centre which was completed in December 1977 is only 1 km away. Within the same distance, the well-equipped Whampoa and Boon Teck Community Centres will be completed in a few months' time. These centres have tennis and squash facilities.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, does the Senior Minister of State realise that the new Whampoa Community Centre will have only one squash court to cater for 19,000 voters?

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Sir, with the very limited resources available, it is not possible to provide squash courts for every constituency. Community centres are not meant only for the residents of that constituency. If there is a community centre nearby, all the residents around, irrespective of any constituency, should make good use of the centre.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, would the Senior Minister of State consider asking the Potong Pasir Constituency to raise resources for building a squash court?

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Thank you very much for the voluntary service.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, that still does not answer my question. I would like my question answered. We could provide the resources. Could the People's Association get the Housing and Development Board to provide us with the land?

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: The People's Association does not provide land.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: If the HDB could provide the land to the People's Association, we will build the squash court.

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: If the hon. Member can tell us the particular piece of land if it is available, we will approach the Land Office.

NATIONAL SERVICE
(Deserters and Defaulters)


    2. Mr S. Dhanabalan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence the extent of desertion by those serving 'National Service and of avoidance by those who are abroad and who are liable for National Service; the action taken against such deserters and defaulters and whether the present measures taken against defaulters who are abroad are adequate.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, since National Service was introduced in 1967, 544 persons evaded National Service by remaining overseas. Of these, 169 were abroad when National Service was introduced and some 100 Singaporeans or more were resident in Christmas Island. The number of defaulters each year is as follows: 
         Year        -         No.

         1967        -         129
         1968        -          31
         1969        -          31
         1970        -          41
         1971        -          55
         1972        -          41
         1973        -          45
         1974        -          53
         1975        -          58
         1976        -          42
         1977        -          18

                    Total      544


    Over the years, this averages 49 a year as compared with some 20,000 enlisted each year.

    In addition, there are 75 defaulters whose whereabouts are unknown but are presumed to be in Singapore. This gives an average of 6.8 per year.

    These are the persons who never turn up for National Service when they are liable to do so. Deserters are those who have served National Service, but found that they did not like it and then decided to abscond. Most of these cases - known as Absent Without

Column: 308

Leave or AWOL in the Army - eventually realised that their decision to abscond was wrong and they accordingly returned to their unit to take their punishment. However, there are some who stay away for a very long time. These may be considered as deserters as distinct from absentees. If we take 31st December 1976 as a cut-off date, there are 74 such National Servicemen, and the numbers against the year in which they absconded are as follows: - 
     Year Deserted                  No.

         1970            -           1
         1971            -           1
         1972            -           2
         1973            -           5
         1974            -          14
         1975            -          21
         1976            -          30

                        Total       74


    The number of deserters seems to be going up year by year. There are several reasons for this. In recent years we have been enlisting youths of poor educational levels and they are more prone to abscond than better educated youths. The drug problem in recent years has doubtless made a contribution to the number of deserters. But part of the increase is more apparent than real. After some time the soldier either gives up or gets caught. He is then deleted from the list of deserters. Therefore, a good number of those deserting in 1974, 1975 and 1976 will eventually return to the army in future years.

    Regarding defaulters who stay abroad, exit control by Immigration keeps numbers to manageable proportions. Those who have registered for National Service and want to go overseas for study or to visit foreign countries are required to furnish a financial bond of a minimum of $50,000 before they are issued with Exit Permits.

    In addition, where a registrant fails to return to Singapore or where a National Serviceman deserts and decides to stay abroad, the governments of those countries concerned are informed of the status of these persons, that is, they are deserters or defaulters from National Service. It is not

Column: 309

likely that the government of any reputable country will want to offer citizenship or permanent residence to such persons.

    The Member asked whether these measures are adequate. On the whole I think we can say that so far they are.

WORK PERMITS FOR BAR GIRLS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Labour (a) how many work permits have been issued to bar girls up to the latest convenient date; (b) what skills do they possess to merit the issue of work permits; and (c) why the issue of work permits to prospective employees in coffee shops, small restaurants/eating houses and provision shops is not as liberal as it has been to bar girls.

Column: 309

WORK PERMITS FOR SHOP ASSISTANTS
AND RESTAURANT EMPLOYEES
(Request for relaxation)


    4. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Labour whether he is aware of the serious labour shortage existing today in coffee shops, small restaurants/eating houses and provision shops, as our young Singaporeans are not interested to work in such places, and, in view of the important role such establishments have played in the economic development of Singapore, if he will consider relaxing the issue of work permits to sponsors applying for permits for their prospective employees.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, with your consent and the concurrence of the hon. Member for Khe Bong, take Questions 3 and 4 together as they are related to each other?

     Mr Speaker: Do you agree, Mr Ho?

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Yes, Sir.

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, our policy has been to issue work permits for work as bar girls and no skills requirement is imposed. Given the nature of the work involved, it is a profession which we do not want to encourage our girls to go into.

Column: 310

The issue of such work permits, therefore, meets a desirable social objective. I do not think the hon. Member for Khe Bong is suggesting that we should be restrictive in our issue of work permits for work as bar girls so as to encourage more of our own women to work as bar girls. He may wish to know that as at the end of January 1978, there were a total of 943 work permits issued for work as bar girls.

    Our work permit policy is also designed generally to promote economic development through providing the required manpower. We are at present facing a tight labour market, especially in the manufacturing and construction sectors. Factories and construction worksites are of greater importance when compared to service establishments like coffee shops, small restaurants/eating houses and provision shops. According to the last available statistics, in 1973 the value added per worker for manufacturing was $12,796 when compared to $4,292 for coffee shops, $5,306 for restaurants and $5,000 for general provision/ sundry shops. Given their economic contribution and that the supply of foreign workers is not inexhaustible, Government must accord priority to factories and worksites.

    Coffee shops, small restaurants/eating houses and provision shops must adjust their operations to cope with the present labour shortage. Coffee shops and small restaurants/eating houses should employ more housewives as part-time help or provide self-service in their establishments. Provision shops should curtail their home delivery service. The hon. Member for Khe Bong has travelled extensively abroad and must have seen how similar establishments operate in the West where labour is even harder to come by. We cannot afford to encourage less then optimum use of manpower in these establishments, especially when we are short of labour. This notwithstanding, we have assisted these establishments to some extent. As at the end of January 1978, the number of work permit holders who were coffee shop and provision shop assistants and restaurant cooks and waiters was 1,412.

EDUCATION OF WORKERS ON JOB
SECURITY AND JOB PROSPECTS


    5. Mr Lim Chee Onn: To ask the Minister for Labour (a) what plans his Ministry has to educate our workers on their responsibilities in increasing job security and job prospects for the labour force; and (b) how these plans relate to those workers who are unorganised or who are members of unions which are not affiliated to the National Trades Union Congress.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Lim Chee Onn.

     Mr Phey Yew Kok (Boon Teck): Mr Speaker, Sir, Question No. 5.

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, the education of workers on their responsibilities in increasing job security and job prospects is a new approach to meet the challenges in our social and economic development. Many factors come into play in this aspect of workers' education. These include correct work attitude, higher skill development, productivity consciousness and industrial discipline. Its success can only be assured through the joint efforts of labour, management and the Government. In the public sector, it not only involves the Ministry of Labour and its statutory body, the National Productivity Board, but also other Ministries such as the Ministry of Education and its statutory body, the Industrial Training Board. Being a process involving values and attitudes, it takes time to nurture and should begin in schools or training institutions before the aspiring workers enter the labour market.

    The Ministry of Labour and its statutory board, the National Productivity Board, have been playing an active role in the field of workers' education. The Ministry has sought to assure both unionised and non-unionised workers that there is social justice with industrial peace through its enforcement of the statutory provisions for labour welfare and against unjustified dismissals and retrenchments. It has also counselled' workers on numerous occasions to observe industrial discipline by not resorting to industrial action but follow proper procedures for

Column: 312

resolution of grievances. It has also through speeches constantly stressed the need for higher productivity, skill development, positive work attitudes and curbing of job-hopping in order to overcome economic difficulties and in the process preserve job security and enlarge job prospects. I am particularly happy to note that hon. Members also have occasion to join the Ministry's efforts to this end by making similar exhortations.

    The National Productivity Board has been promoting vigorously the meaning, significance and benefits of higher productivity as well as the establishment of productivity committees and productivity incentive schemes. Its promotion of greater productivity is directed principally at managers, supervisors, workers and students in upper secondary classes and colleges and national servicemen. A display and training centre featuring productivity concepts and examples has been established and publications and audio-visual productions prepared. Programmes for dissemination of such productivity materials and visits to the display and training centre have been worked out and implemented. In addition, training in various aspects of productivity is being provided to the NTUC and its affiliated unions as well as the National Youth Leadership Training Institute.

    Where productivity committees are concerned, the Board has assisted firms to establish and run such committees. Publications on this subject have been made available. It has advised companies on productivity incentive schemes and scheduled in the near future a tripartite seminar to discuss merit and demerit schemes. Participation in productivity committees and the operation of productivity incentive schemes will contribute to a more responsible labour force.

    Schools and other training institutions are the most appropriate starting points for educating our youth in good work attitudes. The Industrial Training Board recently organised a seminar on "Work Attitudes" with the objective of developing a set of guidelines, recommendations and other rele-

Column: 313

vant materials for the eventual compilation of a formal instruction programme on proper work attitudes and values. Arising from this a "Blue Book" or Trainees' Handbook on Work Ethics and Proper Work Attitudes is being printed for institutional trainees.

    As mentioned earlier, the education process is a tripartite effort. In this connection, the NTUC has made a commendable and significant lead in holding the recent seminar on "Job Creation and Job Loss". The subsequent follow-up courses by its affiliated unions will maintain the momentum in disseminating the message of correct values and work ethics as well as skill development to the rank and file members.

    In time, social and economic forces will condition all the workers in employment to realise that while the Government spares no effort in promoting a healthy investment climate to increase job opportunities, the enhancement of job security and job prospects, in the final analysis, depends to a large extent on them - their willingness to give off their best, to learn patiently the skills required and to accept re-training and further training.

HDB FLATS AND SHOPHOUSES
(Particulars)


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communicatons (a) how many units of Housing and Development Board shops were built in 1977; (b) the total number of flats and shops built since the establishment of the Board in 1960; (c) the number of people now living in HDB flats; (d) how many of the flats have been sold up to the latest convenient date; and (a) how many applicants are on the waiting list to purchase and to rent fiats.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is:

    (a) 1,086 Housing and Development Board shops were built in 1977.

Column: 314



    (b) 286,256 flats and 8,662 shops have been built by the Board since 1960.

    (c) About 1.38 million people, or 59.4% of the total population, are living in HDB flats.

    (d) 145,128 flats have been sold up to 31st December, 1977.

    (e) 49,711 applicants for purchase and 12,625 applicants for rental were on the waiting list as at 31st December, 1977.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, can the Senior Minister of State indicate how long these applicants for purchase and rental of flats have to wait before they can got their flats?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, based on the present rate of building, the waiting period should be approximately two to three years, depending on the choice of locality.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Could the Senior Minister of State not hasten this allocation, Sir?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I have indicated a general period of waiting, but if the applicant is not too choosy about the locality of certain estates, like Woodlands, he could probably have got his flat within six months to a year.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, does the Minister not realise that Woodlands is such a distance away from their places of work?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I do not wish to go into the pros and cons whether Woodlands is suitable or not. But in answer to the Member's question as to whether allocation could be expedited, my reply is that different estates are at different stages of development and that choice of locality will be a factor in the period of allocation.

PAYA LEBAR INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
(Security measures)


    10. Mr Tan Soo Khoon asked the Minister for National Development and Communications (a) if he will give a report on the present security measures implemented at Paya Lebar International Airport for the safety of passengers; (b) if he is satisfied with those measures; and (c) if not, what steps will be taken to improve them.

     The Acting Minister for Culture and Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Sir, the present security measures for the safety of passengers at Paya Lebar Airport are adequate.

    While I should not publicise too much of the details lest effectiveness is affected, a brief description of these security measures would be in order.

    All departing passengers are thoroughly screened with the aid of metal detectors. Body search is also carried out, if necessary. Hand baggage are subject to checks by X-ray machines and manual search. Passengers' luggage to be kept in the holds of the aircraft, which are not accessible to passengers in flight, are also searched or X-rayed by security personnel. Transit passengers who choose to proceed to the departure holding area in the terminal building are security checked before entering the passenger terminal. Airport staff holding passes are also checked before they may enter the restricted departure area.

    All outgoing air mail and postal parcels are subject to X-ray screening.

    X-ray screening is also carried out on hold luggage of arriving passengers.

    The Airport is divided between public and restricted areas. All security sensitive areas such as the aircraft aprons and runway, customs, immigration and health areas as well as baggage areas, are restricted to

Column: 317

airport passholders only. All entry and exit points to the restricted areas are permanently guarded by police personnel who also carry out checks on airport staff entering or leaving the restricted areas.

    The airport is also equipped with closed circuit television cameras that constantly monitor all activities inside the terminal buildings covering both public and restricted areas.

    There are also special police units stationed in the Airport to react immediately to any emergency.

    Sir, the security measures which I have briefly described provide adequate safe-guards for the safety of passengers at Paya Lebar Airport without causing too much inconvenience to passengers or affecting adversely the smooth flow of passengers and other users in and out of the Airport. These measures are constantly reviewed in the light of the prevailing security situation facing all international airports. Adjustments are made whenever considered advisable by our airport security officers.

TOA PAYOH DRIVING TEST CENTRE
(Location)


    12. Mr Ivan Baptist asked the Minister for National Development and Communications the exact location of the proposed driving test centre at Lorong 8, Toa Payoh.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposed new driving test centre will be located at No. 1253, Block J, in the middle of Toa Payoh Industrial Park, off Lorong 8, Toa Payoh. The office for this centre is a factory premises with an area of 210 square metres. In front of this office is a plot of vacant ground which will be metalled and will be used for conducting parking and hill-climbing tests.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, has the Senior Minister of State any plans to ensure the road safety of the pedestrians, especially school children from the many schools in the area? The safety of these children would be greatly endangered by the increased traffic especially of learner drivers with limited driving experience and skill.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I certainly share the concern of the hon. Member, when he raised the supplementary question. The site of this test centre has been chosen after an exhaustive survey of alternative areas in other locations. The sites considered included reverted properties in Changi, Sembawang, Tanglin and Seletar areas. However, these sites have been abandoned because their locations are inconvenient to the majority of learner drivers and instructors. Fringe car parks have also been found unsuitable because of the absence of facilities, such as office premises, toilets and canteens.

    The Toa Payoh test centre is a suitable location as it is sited in an industrial estate adjoining a residential town. It is easily accessible and is convenient to most learner drivers. Moreover, office promises, toilets and canteen facilities are available in the industrial estate.

Column: 319



    I wish to assure the hon. Member that traffic congestion will be minimised. Driving tests will commence at 8.00 a.m. when the schools nearby are already in session. During lunch time, from 1.00 p.m. to 2.00 p.m., no driving tests will be conducted so that the safety of children leaving or going to schools in the area will not be endangered. Driving tuition will also be prohibited on certain selected roads during traffic peak hours. Driving tests will be conducted during non-peak hours and these tests will be spread over 10 different routes to avoid congestion. As I mentioned earlier, the parking and hill-climbing tests will be conducted within the industrial estate. Noise generated will therefore not create any nuisance.

    I hope that what I have described will give the hon. Member the necessary assurance that he needs.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister of State indicate the cost of setting up this test centre?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: The estimated cost of the Toa Payoh driving test centre and the one at Jalan Ubi is about $60,000 for both. I do not have a detailed breakdown of the figure.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, could I seek clarification from the Senior Minister of State whether learner drivers will be allowed to practise late at night? If so, that could cause a terrible nuisance.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Yes, of course they will be allowed to have their lessons at night. It is too early to say whether or not this would create a nuisance. But if it creates a nuisance, we will look into the matter.

ANTI-LITTERING CAMPAIGN
(Revival of)


    13. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology whether he is aware that the bad habit of littering has come back to Singapore, and if he will consider

Column: 320

launching another nation-wide campaign to cultivate the good habit of keeping Singapore clean at all times.

     The Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology (Mr E.W. Barker): Sir, it is true that in some places, such as bus stops and shopping complexes in the city centre, littering has increased. But littering is not so rampant as to warrant a national campaign. Since the launching of the first national "Keep Singapore Clean" campaign in 1968, the majority of the population have become conscious about keeping the environment clean. However, despite rising literacy and affluence and public health education, some people still continue to liner streets, drains and public places.
